## Bioinformatics Project Lifecycle

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}

::: {.r-stack style="position: relative; min-height: 250px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center; text-align: left;"}

<div class="fragment fade-in-then-out" data-fragment-index="1">
Proposal & Funding 
<ul style="font-size:70%">
  <li>Assist in grant writing</li>
  <li>Experimental design planning and choosing the protocol</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="fragment fade-in-then-out" data-fragment-index="2">
Data Generation & Delivery  
<ul style="font-size:70%">
  <li>Coordination with the sequencing core</li>
  <li>Data storage on HiPerGator</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="fragment fade-in-then-out" data-fragment-index="3">
Data Pre-Processing  
<ul style="font-size:70%">
  <li>Rigorous quality control </li>
  <li>Troubleshooting at multiple levels </li>
  <li>MultiQC reports </li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="fragment fade-in-then-out" data-fragment-index="4">
Primary and Secondary Analysis  
<ul style="font-size:70%">
  <li>Use of scalable best-practice pipelines</li>
  <li>Downstream analysis: differential analysis, pathway analysis, tool building etc. </li>
  <li>Access to in-house tools </li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="fragment fade-in-then-out" data-fragment-index="5">
Reports Delivery  
<ul style="font-size:70%">
  <li>Automated project tracking</li>
  <li>Traceable and extensive reports</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class="fragment fade-in-then-out" data-fragment-index="6">
Publication & Data Management  
<ul style="font-size:70%">
  <li>Transfer of analysis files </li>
  <li>Generation of publication quality images</li>
  <li>Uploading files to SRA</li>
</ul>
</div>

:::

:::
:::

::: notes
- People familiar with software development know about the **Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC)**.  
  Similarly, for a bioinformatics project, this is how a typical lifecycle looks with us.  

- **Project Proposal**: We often get involved early, helping collaborators with grant writing (e.g., NIH) and advising on study design, feasibility, and data requirements.  

- **Data Generation & Delivery**: We coordinate with sequencing cores to ensure smooth and well-documented data transfer. Raw FASTQ files are stored on HiPerGator, and we also help set up dedicated PI resources or temporary BCBSR resources.  

- **QC & Pre-processing**: Once data are in hand, we perform QC, processing, and analysis using best-practice pipelines (often ENCODE-based). QC reports summarize results, but a “perfect” QC is rare — troubleshooting may involve revisiting tapestation results, over-digestion, high PCR cycles, or small insert sizes.  

- **Analysis & Interpretation**: We then carry out primary and secondary analyses, working closely with collaborators to ensure findings are biologically meaningful and aligned with their goals.  

- **Reporting & Outputs**: Throughout, collaborators expect transparent communication, reproducible workflows, and clear reports/visualizations. We often assist in manuscript preparation and grant support to help translate analyses into impactful scientific outputs.  
:::

#### <span style="display: block; text-align: center;">Experienced Quality Control Saves Time + Improves Results</span>

:::: {.columns .v-center-container}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](slide_figures/insert-size-good.png){width=100%}
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
![](slide_figures/batch-effect.png){width=80%}
:::
::::

<div style="margin-top:0.4em; font-size:0.8em; line-height:1.3;">

**Catch critical issues early:**

<ul>
  <li>Failed library prep detection</li>
  <li>Contamination identification</li>
  <li>Sequencing quality issues</li>
</ul>

</div>

::: notes
- QC is the foundation of any bioinformatics project — it helps us spot technical problems before they impact results.
- Example 1: The Picard insert size plot showed a very narrow distribution with a shift toward small fragments.  
  This flagged **over-digestion or library prep issues**, which would have biased downstream mapping and peak calling
- Example 2: A PCA revealed strong **batch effects** — samples clustering by sequencing batch rather than biological condition.  
  Without QC, this artifact could easily be mistaken for a biological signal.  
- These checks save time, prevent misinterpretation, and ensure our analyses reflect true biology rather than technical noise.  
:::
